sectionTitle: B.8: Nav Tattva Part III: Samvar, Nirjarä, and Moksh

tabData.tagHTML: In the nine fundamentals (Nav Tattva), Samvar, Nirjarä, and Moksh are the three to be pursued (Upädeya). They represent the active path toward salvation. If Äsrav (influx of karma) is the door through which the disease of karma enters the soul, then:

• Samvar is the closing of that door to prevent new karma.
  • Nirjarä is the medicine that cures the disease by eradicating existing karma.
  • Moksh is the final state of perfect health—total liberation from all karma.

The key to this process is equanimity. By viewing life's situations without attachment or aversion, we can prevent the passions (Kashäy) from arising, which stops the influx of karma (Samvar) and allows us to shed what has already accumulated (Nirjarä).

tabData.title: The 57 Ways of Samvar (Stoppage of Karma)
tabData.description: Jain scriptures outline 57 ways to stop the influx of new karma. Mouse over each node for a description.

nodes.description: Samvar is the process of stopping the influx of new karmic particles to the soul.
Five types of carefulness or awareness in daily activities to ensure non-violence.
Three types of restraint over the activities of mind, speech, and body.
Ten religious virtues that represent the pure, passionless conduct of the soul.
Twelve reflections or contemplations on the fundamental truths of life.
Endurance of 22 types of hardships with complete equanimity.
Five types of conduct, representing different levels of spiritual purity.
Proper care and watchfulness while walking to avoid harming any living beings.
Proper care in speaking to avoid lies, harsh words, or any speech that could cause harm.
Proper care in accepting alms (Gochari), ensuring the food is pure and offered correctly.
Proper care in taking and keeping essential items like clothes or books, ensuring no harm is caused.
Proper care in disposing of bodily waste in a secluded place to avoid harming any life.
Proper control over the mind to prevent impure or sinful thoughts.
Proper control over speech, often by observing silence.
Proper control over the body, keeping it steady and still.
Supreme Forgiveness
Supreme Humility
Supreme Straightforwardness
Supreme Purity/Contentment
Supreme Truthfulness
Supreme Self-restraint
Supreme Austerities
Supreme Renunciation
Supreme Non-attachment
Supreme Celibacy
Contemplation on the impermanence of the world.
Contemplation on the helplessness against death and disease.
Contemplation on the endless cycle of birth and death.
Contemplation on the solitude of the soul.
Contemplation on the separateness of the soul from the body.
Contemplation on the impurity of the body.
Contemplation on the influx of karma.
Contemplation on the stoppage of the influx of karma.
Contemplation on the shedding of karma through austerities.
Contemplation on the nature and transitoriness of the universe.
Contemplation on the rarity of attaining enlightenment.
Contemplation on the rarity of acquiring true religion and a true preceptor.
To remain in a state of equanimity throughout life.
To live the life of an ascetic, correcting any breaches in conduct.
To follow special types of penance as an advanced ascetic.
The conduct of an ascetic who has almost no passions left, except a subtle desire for Moksh.
The perfect, natural conduct of a Kevali (omniscient being), totally free from passions.

tabData.title: The 12 Types of Nirjarä (Shedding of Karma)
tabData.description: Nirjarä is the process of eradicating accumulated karma through austerities (Tap). Mouse over each node for a description.

nodes.description: Nirjarä is the partial eradication of accumulated karma through deliberate effort (Sakäm Nirjarä).
External austerities primarily related to the physical body, which prepare one for internal austerities.
Internal austerities related to purifying the mind and soul, which are the ultimate goal of Tap.
Fasting; complete abstinence from food and/or water for a set period.
Eating less than one's appetite to practice moderation.
Curtailing desires by limiting the number of food items or possessions.
Relinquishing tasty foods (like sweets, fried food, dairy) to conquer the sense of taste.
Voluntarily enduring physical hardships with equanimity (e.g., meditating in heat/cold).
Giving up pleasures of the five senses and occupying minimal space.
Repentance and atonement for any breaches of vows or bad deeds.
Modesty and showing appropriate respect to teachers, elders, and all deserving beings.
Selfless service to monks, nuns, the needy, and those who are suffering.
Study of the self and religious scriptures to understand the true nature of the soul.
Meditation, specifically virtuous meditation (Dharma Dhyän and Shukla Dhyän).
Renunciation of the physical body by withdrawing from all physical, verbal, and mental activities to stay absorbed in the soul.

tabData.title: A Guide to Common Austerities (Tapasyä)
tabData.description: Jainism includes many types of fasts and dietary restrictions as part of its external austerities.

items.content:
Navakärashi: Consuming food/water only 48 minutes after sunrise.
Chauvihär: No food or water after sunset until sunrise the next day.
Tivihär: No food after sunset, but water is permitted once before bed.

Porisi: Consuming food/water only after the first Prahar (approx. 3 hours) of the day.
Purimuddha: Consuming food/water only after two Prahars (midday).

Ekäsan: Eating only one meal a day, in one sitting.
Biyäsan: Eating two meals a day, in two sittings.

Upaväs: A full day of fasting. A Tivihär Upaväs allows boiled water, while a Chauvihär Upaväs does not.
Chhath: Two consecutive days of Upaväs.
Attham: Three consecutive days of Upaväs.

Äyambil: A single meal of boiled or cooked food with no spices, oil, dairy, sugar, or green vegetables.
Navpad Oli: Nine consecutive days of Äyambil.
Varsitap: A year-long austerity of alternate-day fasting.

tabData.tagHTML: Moksh, or liberation, is the ninth and final fundamental. It is the complete and total liberation of the soul from all karma. A soul that achieves Moksh is called a Siddha.

• The soul regains its original, pure attributes of infinite knowledge, infinite perception, infinite energy, and infinite bliss.
  • It is forever freed from the cycle of birth and death.
  • The liberated soul ascends to the top of the universe (Lokäkäsh) and resides there forever in a state of pure consciousness. This place is called Siddha-kshetra.

1. Keval-jnän: This is the state of omniscience, attained when the four defiling (Ghäti) karmas are destroyed. The soul in this state is an Arihant.
2. Nirväna (Moksh): This is the final liberation, which occurs upon the death of an Arihant, when the remaining four non-defiling (Aghäti) karmas are destroyed.
